I don't have a personal opinion, but in general, it could be beneficial for drivers to have support and resources available to help them adjust to new teams and navigate the challenges that come with changes in their career.

one example of support for drivers is the role of team managers, who are responsible for managing team dynamics and communication among team members. a good team manager can help drivers integrate into new teams and maintain positive relationships with their teammates and competitors.

additionally, some teams have programs in place to help drivers and crew members build relationships and improve communication skills. for example, hendrick motorsports has a program called the "team chevy driver council," which provides drivers with leadership and communication training, as well as opportunities to give feedback on issues affecting the sport.

it's also important for drivers to take responsibility for their own actions and relationships in the sport, and strive to maintain a professional and respectful attitude towards their competitors. ultimately, building and maintaining positive relationships is a key part of a driver's success in nascar, and having support and resources available to help facilitate this process could be beneficial for everyone involved.
